Open research problems

1. Automatic ontology localization
2.
Multilingual mappings between ontologies expressed in different languages
3. Models, methods, techniques, and tools for the generation of multilingual Linked Data
4. Services for integrating multilingual ontologies and multilingual Linked Data
Related research problems

Ontology localization

Ontology matching and alignment

Ontology Matching
refers to the activity of finding or discovering relationships or
correspondences between entities of different ontologies or ontology modules. Note: Ontology Matching can be seen as the first stage of Ontology Aligning
Ontology Aligning
refers to the activity of finding the correspondences between
two or more ontologies and storing/exploiting them. A synonym for this activity is
Ontology Mapping.
Ontology Mapping
refers to the activity of finding the correspondences between
two or more ontologies and storing/exploiting them. A synonym for this activity is
Ontology Aligning.
Entity resolution

"MATCHING AND UNIFYING RECORDS IN A DISTRIBUTED SYSTEM"
Database Systems - The Complete Book by Hector Garcia-Molina, Jeff Ullman, and Jennifer Widom, 2002
Evaluating Entity Resolution results - Menestrina, David and Whang, Steven Euijong and Garcia-Molina, Hector

S2. Same domain

Datasets representing the same knowledge domain in different languages (e.g geo, museums, news, etc.)
For this scenario we could use the library domain, without using VIAF as hub and then automatically validate the results based on VIAF cluster.

Dataset linkage

Identificar el grado de uso de las URIS en cada herramienta.
- SILK

How it works?
[13]
What it offers?
(We need to validate these claims for a ML scenario)
Flexible, declarative language for specifying link conditions
Support of RDF link generation (owl:sameAs links as well as other types)
Employment in distributed environments (by accessing local and remote SPARQL endpoints)
Supports OAIE Alignment format
Usable in situations where terms from different vocabularies are mixed and where no consistent RDFS or OWL schemata exist
Scalability and high performance through efficient data handling (speedup factor of 20 compared to Silk 0.2):
Reduction of network load by caching and reusing of SPARQL result sets
Multi-threaded computation of the data item comparisons (3 million comparisons per minute on a Core2 Duo)
Optional blocking of data items
